items.name: Vim
items.description: As a keyboard junkie, Vim suits my needs very well. After dipping my toes in with "Vim-Mode" in other editors, I finally made the jump years ago and haven't looked back.

items.name: iTerm2
items.description: My preferred terminal emulator.

items.name: Cobalt2 theme
items.description: My favorite color scheme. ðŸ’™ðŸ’›

items.name: JetBrains Mono font
items.description: Recent addition, but into it so far. Bonus points for being free and open source.

items.name: my dotfiles
items.description: I try to keep anything else configurable in my dotfiles.

items.name: Ulysses
items.description: I do all of my prose writing in Ulysses. I have groups set up to track progress of different pieces. Writing in Markdown is a must for me, and its comment feature is a game-changer for me. That along with writing goals and reliable sync between devices make it an ideal solution for writing.

items.name: Byword
items.description: For quick one-off documents, I may reach for Byword. Markdown support included.

items.name: Digital Ocean
items.description: New to the platform, but their Droplet system makes getting started much easier (or just possible in the first place). (Note: referral link)

items.name: Netlify
items.description: For static sites (like this one), Netlify is great. Rock solid deployment process, and they do a lot for the community as well.

items.name: Heroku
items.description: For a project with a back-end where I don't want to worry about server infrastructure Heroku is perfect.

items.name: Namecheap
items.description: When buying domain names, I've gone with Namecheap. Some of the cheapest prices around, but from a reputable company.

items.name: Firefox
items.description: Switch back to Firefox after a decade-long hiatus, and happy to see it's still on par with other major browsers. The built-in privacy features (combined with Mozilla's commitment to an open web) definitely make it worth giving Firefox another look.

items.name: Things
items.description: The best to-do app I've used, hands down. Beautiful design and tons of attention has been given to each feature.

items.name: Alfred
items.description: I use Alfred for every web search, as a quick dictionary, and to control Spotify. Super versatile and extensible.

items.name: 1Password
items.description: Been using this password manager forever. If not this one, please find one you like.

items.name: Mailplane
items.description: A native application wrapper around the Gmail interface.

items.name: Fantastical
items.description: An excellent calendar application.

items.name: Backblaze
items.description: Off-site backup is a necessity, and Backblaze has saved me a number of times. (Note: referral link)

items.name: Dash
items.description: A handy resource to quickly look up development documentation.

items.name: SelfControl
items.description: Easily block the websites that are ingrained in your muscle memory.

items.name: Vimium
items.description: Keeps my hands on the keyboard while in my browser. Strong recommend if you already use Vim, or even if you don't.

items.name: 1Password
items.description: Easily autofill your logins in the browser.

items.name: uBlock Origin
items.description: Best ad blocker in the biz.

items.name: Privacy Badger
items.description: Complements a privacy blocklist well by identifying trackers as you browse and denying them.

items.name: HTTPS Everywhere
items.description: Most sites are using HTTPS now, but force it if needed.

items.name: Decentraleyes
items.description: Will improve performance by caching CDN data, and preserving privacy whilst doing so. A win-win.

items.name: Wappalyzer
items.description: Curiosity gets the best of me while browsing, and this lets me keep my finger on the pulse of what technologies other people are using to build web applications.

items.name: Terms of Service; Didnâ€™t Read
items.description: You know you don't read privacy policies, so it's nice to get alerted if there are any red flags as you browse.

items.name: Facebook Container
items.description: A Firefox exclusive, which I could argue is reason enough to switch. Isolates your browsing so that Facebook can't creepily follow you around the net.

items.name: FB Purity
items.description: Interface is ugly as sin, but allows you to block the annoying parts of Facebook.

items.name: Old Reddit Redirect
items.description: For the rare times I find myself on Reddit, this makes the interface tolerable.

items.name: Video Speed Controller
items.description: Convenient video controls that work on any site.

items.name: Metastream
items.description: Remote streaming parties for almost any platform.
